conclusion: To determine when objects A and B are farthest apart, we need to analyze their positions as functions of time.
The position of an object can be found by integrating its velocity with respect to time.
The velocity-time graph shows the velocity \(v\) of each object as a function of time \(t\).
The area under the velocity-time graph gives the displacement of the object from its starting position.
The displacement \(s(t)\) of an object at any time \(t\) is given by the integral of its velocity \(v(t)\) from \(0\) to \(t\): \(s(t) = \int_0^t v(t) \, dt\).
For object A: From \(t=0\) to \(t=t_1\), the velocity is decreasing. From \(t=t_1\) to \(t=t_2\), the velocity is increasing. From \(t=t_2\) onwards, the velocity is constant.
For object B: The velocity starts high, decreases to zero, and then increases again.

premise: The farthest apart the two objects will be occurs when the difference in their displacements is maximized.
conclusion: This happens when the areas under the curves for both objects are most different.
At \(t=t_1\), object A has a higher velocity than object B, but they have not yet diverged significantly.
At \(t=t_2\), the velocities of both objects are equal, and they are still close together.
After \(t=t_2\), object A continues to increase its velocity linearly, while object B also increases but at a slower rate due to its initial high velocity followed by a decrease.

premise: The farthest apart the two objects will be is just before \(t=t_2\), where the difference in their velocities is the greatest.
conclusion: Therefore, the two objects are farthest apart at \(t = t_1\).
